answers.answer: Hello dear and welcome to the medhelp forum. MRI brain shows hyperintensities in the periventricular white matter, sagittal FLAIR images are the most sensitive for MS. Sagittal FLAIR images distinguish between non-specific white matter changes like seen in hypertension, diabetes, age above 50, migraine, smoking and high cholesterol levels.  Your doctor should do a complete blood count, metabolic panel including TSH and B12 levels to rule out other possible diagnosis. CSF evaluation and detection of oligoclonal bands and prolongation of conduction in visual evoked potentials suggest MS diagnosis. For MS diagnosis if you have had at least two relapses or symptomatic episodes, with a month in between and more than one lesion on brain or spinal cord, this is, suggestive of MS.  If your neurologist is able to make an alternative definite diagnosis accounting your symptoms, MS is excluded. MS is a possible diagnosis when your symptoms look like MS but tests are normal. It is usually a definite diagnosis only when you have had at least two attacks, separated in time and minimum two areas of demyelination on MRI. I hope this information only helps you know what to expect and not to cause anxiety. Wish you all the best.

question: I have had headaches for 14 days....waking up with them and going to bed with them.  My vision as well has been affected.  The MRI showed "moderate number of punctate foci of increased signal on the Flair sequences in both the periventricular and subcortical white matter of both hemispheres."  What does that mean?
title: punctate foci and headaches
